title-group.subtitle: The Happy Act on Impulse, the Sad Think Twice

abstract.p: Attitude–behavior relations can be based on belief-based or associative processes. Understanding the basic regulatory mechanisms that determine which type of process guides behavior in a specific situation is of crucial importance for predicting behavior. In this article, the authors tested mood states as a moderator. In two studies, associative and belief-based measures for attitudes were administered in a preliminary session. In a second session, mood was manipulated and behavior toward the attitude object involved was observed. Consistent with predictions, the results showed that in happy mood states, associative, but not belief-based measures of attitudes predicted behavior, whereas in sad mood states belief-based, but not associative measures of attitudes predicted behavior. The authors conclude that mood moderates which evaluative process, belief-based or associative, regulates behavior.

body.p: Behavior is guided by evaluation. Positive evaluations move people to obtain positive outcomes, whereas negative evaluations help them to keep away from negative events. However, claiming that attitudes influence our behavior depicts too simple a picture. Evaluations can be based on distinct processes: spontaneous evaluative associations of attitude objects on the one hand and deliberative integration of explicit beliefs regarding values, expectations, and importance of attributes of attitude objects on the other hand. The outcome of both evaluative processes often is different. For example, to satisfy our desire for something to eat at 4 p.m., we might either spontaneously grab a chocolate bar, or, after deliberating about the pros and cons, take an apple. Therefore, it is of great importance to understand which factors influence which type of evaluation process guides behavior and decision making. Previous work revealed evidence for cognitive and motivational moderators of belief-based versus associative attitude–behavior relations. Our focus is on an omnipresent factor, which constantly fluctuates in daily life, but has been largely neglected in this domain thus far: affective states.

sec.title: From Attitudes to Behavior: Associative Versus Belief-Based Processes
sec.p: Evaluative processing can be considered a dynamic process that starts off with an automatic evaluation phase: The first, spontaneous evaluation that comes to mind. Research on automatic evaluation was inspired by the work of Fazio, Sanbonmatsu, Powell, and Kardes (1986) who were the first to show that attitude objects automatically trigger an evaluation (e.g., “positive”) when an object (“chocolate bar”) is perceived (see also, e.g., Bargh, Chaiken, Govender, & Pratto, 1992; Hermans, Spruyt, & Eelen, 2003; for an overview, see Fazio, 2001). These findings inspired researchers to establish attitude measures, generally labeled as implicit measures of attitudes, targeted at tapping these spontaneous evaluations, such as the Implicit Association Test (IAT; Greenwald, McGhee, & Schwartz, 1998), the Affective Priming paradigm (Fazio, Jackson, Dunton, & Williams, 1995), and the Affect Misattribution Procedure (Payne, Cheng, Govorun, & Stewart, 2005). Multiple studies have revealed that spontaneous evaluations, as measured with implicit attitude measures, predict behavior across various domains, including approach–avoidance motor actions (Chen & Bargh, 1999), food choices (Friese, Hoffmann & Wanke, 2008), amount of consumed candy (Hofmann, Gawronski, Gschwendner, Le, & Schmitt, 2005), and racial interactions (Dotsch & Wigboldus, 2008; Dovidio, Kawakami, Johnson, Johnson, & Howard, 1997; Van den Bergh, Denessen, Hornstra, Voeten, & Holland, 2010; see for overviews, Fazio & Olson, 2003; Friese, Hofmann, & Schmitt, 2008; Greenwald, Poehlman, Uhlman, & Banaji, 2009). Clearly, our spontaneous evaluative associations upon perceiving an object can influence our subsequent decisions and actions.

Often, the evaluative process stops after the automatic evaluation phase. However, when individuals have enough cognitive resources and motivation, the evaluative processes continue and may be altered as a function of beliefs and propositions that are made (Cunningham & Zelazo, 2007; Gawronski & Bodenhausen, 2006). Belief-based attitudes are assumed to depend on the expectancy and evaluation of potential outcomes and their importance (Ajzen, 1985; Ajzen & Fishbein, 1977, 2000, 2005). For example, the attitude toward eating chocolate may be influenced by various outcome expectancies (e.g., likelihood of gaining weight or experiencing great taste), the evaluation of all these outcomes (e.g., gaining weight is bad and experiencing a great taste is nice), and their importance. Behavior guidance by belief-based attitudinal processes can be characterized as a deliberative process, in which individuals elaborate on available information (Ajzen, 2001; Ajzen & Fishbein, 1977, 2000, 2005). A great number of studies have also shown the link between belief-based measures of attitudes and behavior (see for an overview, Ajzen, 2001).

As the evaluative outcomes of belief-based versus evaluative processes are often quite distinct, it is of crucial importance to understand the circumstances that trigger either of the evaluative routes to behavior. Several researchers investigated cognitive moderators, including the controllability of the behavior (e.g., nonverbal vs. verbal behavior; Dovidio, Kawakami, & Gaertner, 2002) and the availability of cognitive resources due to for example ego depletion or cognitive load (e.g., Friese, Hofmann, & Wänke, 2008; Hofmann, Rauch, & Gawronski, 2007). Furthermore, motivational factors have been investigated, such as the motivation to be unprejudiced (e.g., Fazio et al., 1995) and accountability motives (Sanbonmatsu & Fazio, 1990). Results are generally in line with the predictions of Fazio’s MODE model (Fazio, 1990; Fazio & Towles-Schwen, 1999; see also Strack & Deutsch, 2004): A belief-based, reflective route is facilitated when individuals have the opportunity and motivation to process information systematically. So far, affective factors have been neglected in this domain. This is surprising, given the omnipresence of affective states in daily life and their strong influence on cognition and action. In the current article, we therefore aim to contribute to this body of empirical and theoretical work, with a complementing focus on the potential role of mood states as a moderator of associative versus belief-based attitudinal processes in behavior regulation.

sec.title: Mood and the Attitude–Behavior Relationship
sec.p: In line with others, we define mood states as diffuse affective states that last relatively long (e.g., Frijda, 1986, 2007; Russell, 2003). In our daily life, our mood states naturally fluctuate, for example, as a function of our good and bad experiences and they can have a pervasive influence on our thinking and acting. Mood states are assumed to reflect the general state of an individual (e.g., Jacobsen, 1957; Nowlis & Nowlis, 1956) and have been repeatedly shown to influence judgment and decision making (see for overviews, e.g., Forgas, 2008; Schwarz & Clore, 2007), either by influencing what information is activated or by influencing how information is processed. Here, we focus on the latter.

In order to get a good understanding of how mood influences the attitude–behavior relationship, it is important to focus on how mood could trigger behavior as a function of either belief-based evaluative processing or spontaneous evaluative associations.

sec.title: Mood and Belief-Based Attitudes
sec.p: Evidence for enhanced deliberation in sad mood states has been derived from studies in various domains, including persuasion (e.g., Bless, Bohner, Schwarz, & Strack, 1990), analytical reasoning tasks (Fiedler, 1988; De Vries, Holland, Corneille, Rondeel, & Witteman, 2010), fit effects between mood states and deliberative versus intuitive decision strategies (De Vries, Holland, & Witteman, 2008b), and effects of mild depression on attention (e.g., Edwards & Weary, 1993). Several theoretical accounts for the influence of mood on processing style have been proposed, including cognitive tuning, capacity, and motivation accounts (e.g., Mackie & Worth, 1989, 1991; Schwarz, 1990; Wegener & Petty, 1994; Wegener, Petty, & Smith, 1995). Jointly, these models state that compared to happy mood states, sad mood states result in more elaboration of information.

Within the attitude domain, Armitage, Conner, and Norman (1999) showed that attitudes and intentions correlated more strongly in sad compared to happy mood states. However, as attitudes and intentions were measured during the same session, within the same questionnaire, consistency motives rather than differential attitudinal processes may have driven the effects. Moreover, they employed a semantic differential attitude measure, which, as we will elaborate on in the discussion, can be influenced by deliberative processes as the authors suggest, but also by spontaneous evaluative processes. Clearly, more research is necessary, but based on the empirical evidence and theoretical background, we could safely hypothesize that belief-based evaluative processes, known to require more deliberation, more strongly influence behavior in sad compared to happy mood states.

sec.title: Mood and Automatic Evaluation
sec.p: A stronger reliance on spontaneous evaluations—as can be captured by implicit attitude measures—in happy compared to sad mood states is predominantly predicted by tuning accounts of mood (e.g., Bless & Schwarz, 1999; Clore, Schwarz, & Conway, 1994; Schwarz, 2002), or more specifically the affective processing principle (Clore & Huntsinger, 2009). Happy mood states are associated with safe environments and therefore function as a go signal. Consequently, individuals tend to go along with their dominant responses (e.g., activated knowledge). In contrast, sad mood states are associated with problematic environments and function as a no-go signal, making individuals reluctant to use currently activated knowledge (cf. Bless & Schwarz, 1999).

The affective processing principle may account for a number of findings. For instance, happy mood compared to sad mood individuals more strongly rely on stereotypes (e.g., Bodenhausen, Kramer, & Süsser, 1994), heuristics (e.g., Ruder & Bless, 2003), scripts (e.g., Bless et al., 1996), and peripheral cues (Bless, Mackie, & Schwarz, 1992; Schwarz, Bless, & Bohner, 1991). Furthermore, evidence indicates that happy compared to sad individuals more strongly rely on stored associations (Hänze & Hesse, 1993; Vermeulen, Corneille, & Luminet, 2007; Vermeulen, Luminet, & Corneille, 2006; see also reported evidence in Clore & Huntsinger, 2009) and spontaneous affective reactions (De Vries, Holland, & Witteman, 2008a). Most relevant, Huntsinger, Sinclair, and Clore (2009) showed that the automatic component of evaluation, using the process dissociation paradigm, is stronger in happy compared to sad mood states.

Thus, according to the affective processing principle, it may be predicted that, compared to sad mood participants, happy mood individuals more strongly rely on their spontaneous evaluative associations. Therefore, we hypothesized that implicit measures of attitudes are better predictors of behavior in happy compared to sad mood states.

sec.title: Overview of the Current Research
sec.p: In two studies, we tested the hypothesis that in happy mood states, implicit but not belief-based measures of attitudes predict behavior, whereas in a sad mood state belief-based measures, but not implicit attitude measures predict behavior.

In Study 1, we measured the implicit attitude (Study 1a) or belief-based attitude (Study 1b) toward blood donation. In a second session, mood was manipulated and a behavioral measure was administered. In Study 2, both the implicit and the belief-based attitudes toward apples and candy bars were measured. Subsequently, the choice of an apple or candy bar (Karpinski & Hilton, 2001) was observed. Together, these experiments systematically test the hypothesized moderating role of mood in whether belief-based or associative evaluative processes are dominant in shaping behavior.

sec.title: Overview
sec.p: In a preliminary session, participants’ attitudes toward blood donation were measured. We used an implicit attitude measure in Study 1a, and an explicit, belief-based attitude measure in Study 1b. Two weeks later, participants watched one of two video fragments to induce either a happy or sad mood state. Subsequently, attitude-relevant behavior was observed.

sec.title: Participants and design
sec.p: In Study 1a, 47 students (9 men) and in Study 1b, 57 students (11 men) of the Radboud University Nijmegen participated, receiving money in return for their participation. Students participated in one study only, either Study 1a or Study 1b. In both studies, participants were randomly assigned to the cells of a two (Mood: Sad vs. happy) single factor between-subjects design.

sec.title: Study 1a: implicit measure of attitudes
sec.p: In Study 1a, attitudes toward blood donation were measured by means of a Single Target IAT (ST-IAT; Bluemke & Friese, 2008; Wigboldus, Holland, & Van Knippenberg, 2005). In the ST-IAT, consisting of three blocks each including 16 trials, participants had to categorize positive and negative adjectives as well as words concerning blood donation by pressing one of two keys. The ST-IAT started with a practice block in which only the positive adjectives (e.g., pleasure) and negative adjectives (e.g., awful) were used. Participants were instructed to indicate as fast as possible whether a word was positive or negative. In the following two blocks, blood donation words (blood donation, blood donor, give blood, and blood bank) were presented as well. In the “positive” (“negative”) block, the positive (negative) adjectives and blood donation words were under the same key, while the negative (positive) adjectives were under the other key. In order to equal the number of left and right responses, each negative (positive) adjective was presented twice. The order of the negative and positive blocks was counterbalanced between subjects. Item order within blocks was randomized. An attitude index was created, after removing responses below 300 ms or above 3,000 ms (0.09%) and error responses (3.01%), by subtracting the log-transformed response times in the positive block from the log-transformed response times in the negative block, with higher scores indicating more positive attitudes toward blood donation.

sec.title: Study 1b: belief-based measure of attitudes
sec.p: Belief-based attitudes toward blood donation were measured in accordance with expectancy-value models of attitudes (Ajzen & Fishbein, 2000). Likelihood, evaluation, and importance of 15 attitude attributes were measured. These attributes were either positive (e.g., blood donation helps others) or negative (e.g., blood donation hurts). First, the subjective likelihood was assessed for each attribute on scales ranging from 1 (definitely not) to 7 (definitely). Second, for each attribute, participants evaluated the attribute on scales ranging from −3 (very negative) to +3 (very positive). Finally, attribute importance was assessed by asking participants to select 5 of the 15 attributes that they personally considered most important. An attitude index was created based on those five most important attributes (cf. Van der Pligt, De Vries, Manstead, & Van Harreveld, 2000). Likelihood and evaluation scores were multiplied for each of these attributes and subsequently summed across attributes. Higher scores indicated more positive attitudes toward blood donation.

sec.title: Mood manipulation
sec.p: Two weeks after the preliminary session in which attitudes toward blood donation were measured, participants returned to the laboratory. First, mood was manipulated with using 3-min film fragments. For the happy condition, a fragment of “the Muppets” was used. For the sad condition, a fragment of the movie “American History X” was used in Study 1a and a fragment of the movie “Schindler’s List” was used in Study 1b. Participants were asked to especially pay attention to the funny or sad parts, respectively.

sec.title: Behavioral measure
sec.p: After the film clips, we observed a behavioral interest in becoming a blood donor. Participants filled in a form on blood donation, which asked for participants’ name, address (including street, zip code, and city), telephone number, and e-mail address. The behavioral measure concerning eagerness to get information about becoming a blood donor consisted of the number of personal details that participants filled out on the form (0–7). Finally, an affect questionnaire was given to the participants, asking how negative, sad, angry, positive, satisfied, and happy they felt (α = .92), on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 9 (very much). Afterwards, the participants were thanked and debriefed.

sec.title: Preliminary analyses
sec.p: In both Studies 1a and b, participants expressed more positive affect in the happy mood condition (Study 1a: M = 6.81, SD = 1.17; Study 1b: M = 6.96, SD = 1.09), compared to the sad mood condition (Study 1a: M = 5.78, SD = 1.88; Study 1b: M = 5.68, SD = 1.61), F(1,45) = 5.07, p < .05, η2 = .10 and F(1,55) = 12.21, p < .01, η2 = .18, respectively. On average, participants provided only a few information items (Study 1a: M = 1.98, SD = 2.91; Study 1b: M = 2.72, SD = 2.96), with 34% (Study 1a) and 54% (Study 1b) of the participants providing at least one item of information.1

sec.title: Implicit measure of attitudes
sec.p: The amount of information given by the participant on the blood donation interest measure was regressed on the standardized measure of ST-IAT, mood condition (dummy coded −1 for sad and +1 for the happy condition), and the interaction term. This revealed the predicted ST-IAT × Mood Interaction, β = .40, t(43) = 2.33, p < .05. No other effects were found (ps > .23).

Simple slope analyses showed that within the sad mood condition, ST-IAT scores were unrelated to the amount of personal information that was provided, β = −.19, t(43) = −1.14, ns. In the happy mood condition, however, the participants with negative attitudes toward blood donation gave less personal information than those who were positive toward blood donation, β = .60, t(43) = 2.03, p < .05 (Figure 1a).

caption.p: A. Amount of personal information given as a function of the Single Target-Implicit Association Test (ST-IAT) for the mood conditions. Higher ST-IAT scores mean a more positive implicit attitude toward blood donation: (Study 1a). Amount of personal information given as a function of the expectancy-value model for the mood conditions. Higher belief-based attitude scores imply a more positive attitude toward blood donation (Study 1b).

sec.title: Belief-based measure of attitudes
sec.p: Similar analyses were conducted for the belief-based measure of attitudes in Study 1b. The behavioral interest measure was regressed on the standardized index of the belief-based measure, mood condition, and the interaction term. The analyses revealed a significant Attitude × Mood Interaction, β = −.32, t(53) = −2.50, p < .05. No other effects were found (ps > .12).

Simple slope analyses revealed that, within the happy mood condition the belief-based attitude toward blood donation was unrelated to amount of personal information given, β = −.13, t(53) = −.73, ns. As expected, in the sad mood condition, individuals with negative belief-based attitudes toward blood donation gave less personal information than those who were positive toward blood donation, β = .53, t(53) = 2.69, p < .01 (Figure 1b).

sec.title: Study 2
sec.p: Study 2 aimed to conceptually replicate and extend Studies 1a and b. Most importantly, we now included both an implicit and a belief-based measure for every participant, enabling to test the predictive value of both measures within subjects. Second, we tested our ideas in a different attitude domain. Participants made a choice between receiving an apple or a candy bar (see e.g., Friese, Hoffmann & Wanke, 2008).

sec.title: Overview
sec.p: In a first session, participants first received the personalized IAT on apples and candy bars, followed by a belief-based measure on the same objects. Three or more days later, mood was manipulated and the choice for an apple or a candy bar was observed.

sec.title: Participants and design
sec.p: Eighty-five undergraduates (18 males) at the Radboud University Nijmegen participated in both sessions of this study in return for 3 Euros and were randomly assigned to the happy or sad mood condition. The data of two participants were removed as they did not watch the entire film fragment.

sec.title: Implicit attitude measure
sec.p: The implicit attitude toward apples and candy bars was measured with a personalized IAT (for a full description, see Olson & Fazio, 2004), which is a better predictor in the apple–candy paradigm than a regular IAT (Karpinski & Hilton, 2001; Olson & Fazio, 2004).

The format of the personalized IAT is identical to the original IAT, except that idiosyncratic processes are facilitated by the fact that participants categorize objects (e.g., coffee, television, and opera) in terms of “I like” versus “I dislike” instead of categorizing clearly positive and negative adjectives (e.g., “great” or “bad”) on the basis of their valence. Error feedback was provided on the category words only.

An IAT score of every participant was calculated by subtracting the log-transformed reaction times of the block in which candy bars and the “I like” words were under the same key from the log-transformed reaction times of the block in which candy bars and the “I dislike” words were under the same key. Then, a positive IAT score indicates a positive implicit attitude toward candy bars relative to apples and a negative IAT score indicates a positive implicit attitude toward apples relative to candy bars.

sec.title: Belief-based attitude measure
sec.p: Participants were asked to rate the likelihood, evaluation, and importance of five attributes concerning apples (e.g., apples are healthy, apples can be sour) and five attributes concerning candy bars (e.g., candy bars are delicious, candy bars are unhealthy). These attributes were selected on the basis of importance ratings of 15 attributes in a pretest. The likelihood and evaluation were rated on a 7-point scale (1 definitely not to 7 definitely and −3 very negative to +3 very positive, respectively).

Belief-based attitude indexes were created for both apples and candy bars in similar ways as in Study 1b. Subsequently, the attitude score for apples was subtracted from the attitude score for candy bars, creating an index of the relative attitude toward candy bars as opposed to apples. Thus, a positive score means a more positive belief-based attitude toward candy bars compared to apples, while a negative score means a more positive belief-based attitude toward apples compared to candy bars.

sec.title: Behavioral measure
sec.p: The behavior studied (the dependent variable) was the choice between an apple and a candy bar. For that purpose, a table was arranged on which a variety of apples and candy bars were displayed. Specifically, a box divided in 8 segments (2 rows of 4) was filled with 4 types of apples (e.g., Granny Smith) and 4 types of candy bars (e.g., Snickers). The segments were labeled with the product name. In Figure 2 , the display of the apples and candy bars is illustrated.

caption.p: The display of apples and candy bars used in Study 2.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: First, participants responded to the personalized IAT. Next, they completed the computerized questionnaire for the belief-based attitude measure. The order of the attitude objects in the belief-based measure was counterbalanced. Three or more days later, participants returned to the laboratory. We employed the same mood induction as in Study 1b. After watching the video, the experimenter guided the participant into the room in which the apples and candy bars were displayed. The experimenter explained that the participant could choose something from the box as a token of our appreciation. Subsequently, the participants filled out the same mood questionnaire (α = .91) as used in Studies 1a and b.

sec.title: Preliminary analyses
sec.p: Participants in the happy mood reported a more positive mood state (M = 7.08, SD = 1.46) than participants in the sad mood condition (M = 6.28, SD = 1.41), F(1,81) = 6.43, p < .05, η2 = .07. On average, apples were slightly less popular (chosen by 47%) than chocolate bars (53%). The IAT score and the belief-based attitude score did not correlate, r(83) = .15, ns.

sec.title: Attitude–behavior link
sec.p: A logistic regression with mood condition, IAT Score, Belief-Based Attitude Score, Mood × IAT Score, Mood × Belief-Based Attitude Score, IAT Score × Belief-Based Attitude Score, and Mood × IAT Score × Belief-Based Attitude Score was performed on the choice for an apple or a candy bar. The analysis revealed a marginally significant main effect of mood condition, B = 1.00, Wald = 3.25, Exp(B) = 2.73, p = .07, such that positive mood was associated with a higher probability of taking a candy bar.

More importantly, the predicted Mood × IAT score interaction was found, B = 1.83, Wald = 4.61, Exp(B) = 6.24, p < .05. In a happy mood, a stronger preference on the IAT for candy bars led to a higher probability of choosing a candy bar, B = 1.25, Wald = 6.48, Exp(B) = 3.47, p < .05. In the sad mood condition, the IAT was unrelated to behavior, B = −.59, Wald = .71, Exp(B) = .56, ns. In Figure 3 , this interaction is displayed.

caption.p: Probability of selecting a candy bar to an apple as a function of the IAT score for the mood conditions. Higher scores on the personalized IAT indicate a preference for candy bars (Study 2).

sec.p: The logistic regression analyses also revealed an effect of the Mood × Belief-Based Attitude Score Interaction, B = −1.78, Wald = 5.28, Exp(B) = .17, p < .05. In the happy mood condition, no consistency was found between belief-based attitude and behavior, B = −.12, Wald = .07, Exp(B) = .89, ns. On the other hand, sad mood resulted in greater consistency between belief-based attitudes and behavior, B = 1.66, Wald = 6.79, Exp(B) = 5.26, p < .05. In this condition, positive belief-based attitudes toward candy bars led to a higher probability of choosing a candy bar than an apple. This interaction is displayed in Figure 4. No other effects were found, ps > .65.

caption.p: Probability of taking a candy bar to an apple as a function of the belief-based attitude for the mood conditions. Higher scores on the belief-based attitude measure indicate a preference for candy bars (Study 2).

sec.title: General Discussion
sec.p: The goal of the current research was to test the role of affective states as a moderator of attitude–behavior relations. Our hypotheses were based on the well-demonstrated link between affective state and information processing, with sad mood states linked with a deliberative processing style and happy mood states linked with a spontaneous or intuitive processing style (e.g., Bless et al., 1990; De Vries, Holland, Chenier, Starr, & Winkielman, 2010; Fiedler, 1988). In two studies, across different behavioral domains, we showed that implicit measures of attitudes predict behavior in happy but not in sad mood states, while belief-based measures of attitudes predict behavior in sad but not in happy mood states.

Our findings provide clear evidence that mood determines by which evaluative process behavior is guided. Implicit measures of attitudes capture spontaneous evaluative processes, that is, first evaluations that come to mind when confronted with an attitude object. Thus, our findings provide evidence that happy mood states facilitate spontaneous attitude–behavior links. In contrast, the belief-based attitude measure is based on various explicit beliefs and evaluations about these beliefs. In this case, an attitude is based on the analysis and integration of these beliefs. Thus, our findings that belief-based measures of attitudes were more predictive of behavior in sad mood states compared to happy mood states fully corroborate our prediction that sad mood states trigger more deliberative attitude–behavior relations. Just by a change in mood state (e.g., through music, social interaction, or weather conditions) from happy to sad or vice versa, the behavioral outcome may change accordingly, as individuals base their behavior on a different type of evaluative processes.

Our aim was to introduce affect as a moderator of attitude–behavior processes. Thus, we focused on the type of evaluative processes that mood brings about rather than testing how mood brings about these processes. Still, it is worthwhile to ponder on the possible mechanism. One possibility is that happy mood reduces the opportunity to deliberate as has been suggested in earlier work (Mackie & Worth, 1989, 1991). However, various studies have clearly shown that when explicitly instructed to process information in a deliberative fashion, happy mood individuals are able to do so (e.g., Bless, Clore, Schwarz, Golisano, Rabe & Wolk, 1996; Ruder & Bless, 2003).

Then, can mood effects be subsumed under motivation? The MODE model assumes that “some motivational force is necessary to induce individuals to engage in the reasoning” (Fazio & Towles-Schwen, 1999, p. 100). Cognitive tuning models of mood stress that affective states have a signal function concerning the current state of the environment (e.g., Bless & Schwarz, 1999; De Vries et al., 2010; cf. Kuhl & Koole, 2004). Whereas happy mood states signal that the environment is benign, sad mood states signal that the environment might pose a problem that needs to be handled. In such instances, it is functional to mobilize energy such that we may get a better understanding of our situation and we may be better able to solve the problem. This way, mood may be subsumed under the very general term “some motivational force,” but the nature of the motivation is quite different from the specific goals that triggered motivation for deliberation in previous research on the MODE model, such as accuracy goals (Sanbonmatsu & Fazio, 1990) or the motivation not to be prejudiced (Fazio et al., 1995).

As enhanced motivation to deliberate is not exclusively predicted by cognitive tuning models of mood (e.g., Wegener & Petty, 1994, see for overviews Forgas, 2008; Isen, 2008; Martin & Clore, 2001) the exact mechanisms by which mood affects attitude–behavior processes await further empirical scrutiny. One interesting method to reveal the underlying process is to test the influence of mood on attitude–behavior processes when processing capacity is reduced (e.g., under cognitive load). Although most theoretical models on mood and attitudes would predict reduced capacity to result in spontaneous processing among sad mood individuals, cognitive tuning models predict sad mood individuals to abandon reliance on knowledge that quickly comes to mind (cf. Brinol, Petty, & Barden, 2007; Vermeulen et al., 2007). Such designs may help better understand the nature of the mechanism by which affective states influence attitude–behavior relations.

Finally, it is of importance to discuss the nature of so-called explicit attitudes. In many recent studies, researchers employed semantic differentials (e.g., Armitage et al., 1999), measuring evaluations by explicit responses ranging from very negative to very positive. However, evaluative responses on such explicit measures can either be based on spontaneous evaluations or “gut feelings” or on more deliberative evaluative processes depending on the context and level of motivation (Gawronski & Bodenhausen, 2006). In contrast, the belief-based measure, as employed in the current research is much more closely related to the deliberative process, making this measure more suitable for testing the two types of evaluative processes in relation to behavior.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: To conclude, the current set of studies provides convergent evidence that the mood state of individuals moderates how attitudes influence behavior, either in a spontaneous or a more belief-based fashion. In a happy mood state, individuals tend to act on impulse, whereas in a sad mood state, individuals tend to think twice.
